One thing that really gets me about comprehension methods is when people use nuclear bombs as a method to help people comprehend the scale of something. Unfortunately, most people who use this method forget to include WHICH nuclear bomb they're talking about.  Are we talking about "Little Boy" (Hiroshima) at 15 kilotons or are we talking about Tsar Bomba (USSR) at 50 megatons? Tsar Bomba that was actually detonated by the USSR was 3,000 times more powerful than Little Boy.  If Tsar Bomba had employed a depleted uranium tamper instead of a lead tamper, the yield would have been around 100 megatons, over 6,000 times more powerful than Little Boy. It seems like a nitpicky thing to be concerned about but if we're talking about science, numbers matter.

@Physics Girl...
If "gravity" actually existed, gravity would be an all-powerful natural physical force that would indiscriminately pull "all" objects down to the earth regardless of their buoyancy.

Therefore, if "gravity" existed when dropping a tiny pebble into a body of water such as an ocean or a lake, then the tiny pebble would be pulled down to the deepest depths of the bottom floor level of the body of water which is exactly what the tiny pebbled does indeed do when the tiny pebble is dropped into a body of water.

However, when dropping an air balloon filled with helium, the helium-filled air balloon rises into the atmosphere instead of falling down to planet earth or being pulled down to planet earth as should be the case if the all-powerful natural physical force of "gravity" actually existed.

Question: If so-called "gravity" is an all-powerful natural physical force strong enough to prevent people from flying off the surface of the earth while planet earth is rotating/spinning at an allegedly1,000 miles per hour, then surely so-called "gravity" could prevent a helium-filled air balloon from being hurled off the surface of the earth.

The rising helium-filled air balloon is irrefutable evidence that so-called "gravity" does not exist, because if the all-powerful indiscriminate natural physical force of "gravity" actually existed, then not even a helium-filled air balloon could be hurled off the surface of planet earth causing the air balloon to rise into the atmosphere.

If so-called "gravity" is such an all-powerful natural physical force that can keep giant bodies of water (oceans) from being hurled off the surface of planet earth, then surely so-called "gravity" could prevent a tiny helium-filled air balloon from being hurled off the surface of planet earth as is the case when the helium-filled air balloon rises into the atmosphere.

While the processes that generate gravitational waves can be extremely violent and destructive, by the time the waves reach Earth they are thousands of billions of times smaller! 5,798 comments is hard to fathom.  The mind boggles.  I feel like I should don a plastic de-boggler head covering to attempt an initial de-bogglerization.  Can't help but feel that a basic key-word-search capacity for comments (a database after all) might have helped me to know if anyone felt not merely sad at our aesthetic mistakes in the desert (concrete, really?) but whether our requirement for tranquility in our search for distant meaning isn't mirrored at the level of form by the need of the animals we displace here for their own tranquility.  Desert animals need silence.  We need silence to perform the experiment.  Could we really not have worked together?  We're clever monkeys with clever hands, but the mind boggles at the number of tranquility-seeking animals we shove to the margins with such quests.  I'll start the bidding with a million.  Do I hear ten million?  Anyone?  I can't help wonder if the quest isn't undone by such sloppiness.  I speak here as a man very aware of the charms of this girl as she presents the quest.  But perhaps, hmm, she is good-copping something voracious in our knowledge quest, something possibly fatally flawed in the quest itself.  Are there none among us hairless apes with the wisdom or even cleverness to match form and content here?  Could we not find twenty square kilometres elsewhere?  Our species cannot stop fidgeting so we kill the animals who have figured it out?  I thought the desert was the place our species might go for wisdom.  Perhaps a wiser species would have found tranquility first, then reached for the stars.  I write here deep in the basement of the internet, invisible, silenced by the weight of the 5,798 comments above.  But that silence, too, might have about it something of the lineaments of wisdom.  If we don't find what we seek within, we will never find it in the stars.  But we all know this already.

So far, it seems to me, there may be other explanations for this extremely weak wave measurement. For instance, this energy wave could be caused by the planetary-wide physical pulsations of the Earth itself [1] ; or it could be caused by pulsations in the Earth's lower ionosphere synchronized with solar flare emission [2] ; or it could be caused by quantum fluctuations, a kind of churning of transient particles and fields that occurs even in empty space [3] ; or by the harmonic and dissonant resonance of multiple wave sources. Gravity waves are still theoretical until we can include and then eliminate some more variables, even get some off-planet data. Perhaps it wouldn't be too difficult to set up another gravitational wave detector on the moon. Afterall, the vacuum is already there so there would be no need for the metal tubing... just the laser, splitter and detectors. Unfortunately, that would still not discount quantum fluxuations, cosmic radiation fluxuations, variations of solar emissions caused by: the pulsations of the sun, solar storms, flares, solar wind, and/or a plethora of other non-constant energy-wave emissions.

[3] https://scienceandtechblog.com/quantum-jitter-lets-heat-travel-across-a-vacuum/

7:19 just for fun, 1 followed by 30 zeros is a nonillion. In the US at least. Apparently in Britain it's 54 zeros, (or 54 noughts) which actually makes more sense because 54 is a multiple of 9 and 6 (non in nonillion meaning 9, like oct in octillion meaning 8) and they just divide the number of decimal places by six to determine the prefix. The US system for super big numbers is weird but the prefix stands for how many sets of 3 decimal places you add to 1,000. So bi being a prefix for two, you add two sets to 1,000 and you get 1,000,000,000 or a billion. Tri = 3 so add three sets (each set being 3 zeros) and you get 1,000,000,000,000 or a trillion. If you think of 1,000 as your first set, just add whatever the prefix calls for, so with a decillion you add ten sets to your existing set giving you 11 sets of zeros. After decillion it gets weirder but you can still make sense of it. Un is French for one, so an undecillion is a decillion with one set of zeros added to it, giving you 12 sets (almost arrogantly confusing, I know, but it's consistent enough to remember) so the next number is duodecillion which is 13 sets of zeros, giving you 39 zeros. At this point the British system still makes MUCH MUCH more sense in that a duodecillion is 12 x 6 zeros or 72 zeros.

I only took one semester of math in college, so if I got something wrong, feel free to correct me. this is just something I've been thinking about a lot lately because until I realized why the US names numbers the way it does I found the system to be completely nonsensical. I mean.... I still find it nonsensical but at least I can translate it now. I'm sure this is old hat to Physics Girl and probably most of the people who watch this channel.
EDIT: apparently the British system I mention is no longer used? if so, that's a shame, it makes so much more sense, but I guess it's better to have one single system than two that contradict one another. (even if the system is bonkers)

This got my like, but a couple of things could use some clarification. Spacetime is only an analogy or model that helps describe the way things in space behave, not what space itself actually is, and therefore LIGO isn't measuring changes in "space" but changes in the way things in space like the LIGO detector behave when affected by forces such as gravity acting on it. In this case, so-called gravity waves aren't "waves" in space. Rather, they are fluctuations in the gravitational strength of systems such as orbiting neutron stars or colliding black holes.

So when you hear people equating actual space with "spacetime" you're hearing someone who is confusing an abstract geometric model with reality. When Black holes collide they don't "convert energy to gravity waves" they convert mass to energy and the reduction in mass creates a change in the gravitational strength of the system, which in-turn affects other systems, including LIGO.

What is space then? That is a more complex question that it seems, but in simplest terms, space itself is simply a 3D realm and time is the change that happens to stuff in that realm; hence time as a "dimension" is synonymous with the words "factor" or "facet" or "variable", not as another spatial "dimension". The word "dimension" is a poor and confusing choice for "t" as a variable.

Matter bends spacetime, and the effect of that bending of spacetime is to create a generalized kind of force that acts on objects. However, it isn't a force as such that acts on the object, but rather just the
object following its geodesic path through spacetime.
When light passes through an electromagnetic field, it is split into different spectral lines. That electrical phenomenon is what astronomers mistake for gravitational redshift.

Electromagnetics ,on the other hand,are the only force that exists,and can be defined in realtime computational modeling. We are pushed onto earth by the electromagnetics of electrons/proton phasing , as opposed to the theory that gravity holds us to the earth the closer we are to it. When using surface gravity as a function of mass and radius (and sometimes speed of rotation). Density is relevant, but it's not a complete answer. Most of the matter in the universe is in the form of plasma.
 A plasma is formed if some of the negatively charged electrons are separated from
their host atoms in a gas, leaving the atoms with a positive charge. The negatively charged electrons, and the positively charged atoms (known as positive ions) are then free to move separately under the influence of an applied voltage or magnetic field. You wouldn't pronounce the term millimeter "mill-OM-it-er" and you wouldn't pronounce the term centimeter "cen-TIM-it-er" . The pronunciation "kill-OM-it-er" was invented for uneducated American soldiers who fought for Europe in WWI. They  had trouble pronouncing kilometer correctly, but they could pronounce "speedometer" from a car's dashboard, so that pronunciation was close enough for the Army officials. Does Gravity Travel at the Speed of Light?
In the simple newtonian model, gravity propagates instantaneously: the force exerted by a massive object points directly toward that object's present position. For example, even though the Sun is 500 light seconds from the Earth, newtonian gravity describes a force on Earth directed towards the Sun's position "now," not its position 500 seconds ago.
Putting a "light travel delay" (technically called "retardation") into newtonian gravity would make orbits unstable, leading to predictions that clearly contradict Solar System observations So Newton was wrong. They Forgot to tell you at school.

The "speed of gravity" is somewhat of a misnomer.  Gravity is a force that imparts motion that can be measured as a speed.  Gravity therefore has a nearly innumerable amount of speeds.  The maximum speed created by gravity would be directly related to a maximal amount of mass: the most massive object imparting gravitational force on another, with the least amount of drag.  Essentially two colliding singularities.  Light has mass.  Light does not travel at one consistent speed through all mediums.  The maximum speed of light is only approximated and is yet unknowable.  12,000 kilometers is an insignificant span in the consideration of measuring the speed of light, and reductions of speed are not accounted for in LIGO's reflections.  Space is not a perfect vacuum.

Gravitational waves propagate at the speed of light. The waves were detected at the same moment the light from events that happened millions of years ago reached us. This means that these waves were affected by the same gravitational lensing and distortions that light from the same source passed through. Gravity affected gravity, or is it that space itself is distorted by gravity. If this is what happens, then gravity in the vicinity of very large masses may be incorrectly being measured because all of the gravitational waves may not be escaping the black hole, or may have time/space distortions affecting them. This begs one question, if light cannot escape a black hole, how does gravity, affected by the same time/space distortions, escape? It does, but does the extreme environment have some effect one the measurements that we take.
Taking one angle on this, if a gravitational wave is emitted and takes a million years, relative time, to carry it's impulse, is that impulse (f=m/d) equal to the distance we measure as observers, or relative to the graviton's time/space?

Ok I have several questions.
1) How do they know that the two facilities didn’t simply have a similar noise signal at the same time? It seems likely that this would happen frequently over time spans of years.
2) How do they know the gravitational wave came from the colliding black holes? The source cannot be triangulated with fewer than 4 detectors and the error over such a large distance and narrow detector must be massive.
3) Bouncing the laser 300 times along the tube length is trading accuracy for precision. I understand they need better precision to detect such small deltas but how do they account for the lost accuracy?
4) How do they know gravitational waves move at or near the speed of light? Correlating with a coincident astronomical observation is backwards reasoning. If gravity waves were slower then the astronomical event might have happened before recorded history. And if gravity waves are faster then we would not see it yet.
5) Why would waves dissipate in magnitude like light? If spacetime is expanding then wouldn’t the gravity waves dissipate faster?
6) how do they know the distance to the blackhole? Parallax has error. Standard candles have error. Red shift has error. Black holes do not emit. Inference of distance based on other objects behind blackholes has error. Is all that error accounted for in the gravitational wave analysis?
7) how do they account for the orientation of the detectors? A gravity wave parallel to one of the shafts would have a much larger distortion than a gravity wave perpendicular to the shaft. So the magnitude of the signal would be dependent on orientation of the detector rather than the magnitude and distance of the source.

Interestingly, Amateur Radio operators have had the chance to experiment with (GGM) Gravity-Gradient Modulation since the mid-1980's. There was a technical article about it in the April 1986 issue of QST magazine. Effectively, by suspending a piece of Anti-Matter in an electromagnetic field, then modulating this EM field, you could create gravity waves that would follow the curvature of the Earth. Someone on the other side of Earth could then 'De-Modulate' the signal using the same technique. Initial tests were using morse code, but eventually they tried more advanced modulation techniques, such as (SSB) Single-Sideband. This article is what got me interested in radio experimentation.

The Sinoatrial node or the SA Node of our hearts beat independently from the brain. We don’t think to make our heart pulse the way it does. The only input our brain has on our hearts is via the Autonomic Nervous System or ANS. More precisely, the sympathetic (beat faster) or parasympathetic (beat slower) fibers. The most important thing you neglected to mention is that the sensitivity of LIGO is to wave amplitude, not wave energy flux. Amplitude drops linearly with distance, unlike flux which drops as the square. This means future LIGO developments have much more promise for seeing smaller events farther away than typical developments in optical (or radio, IR, UV, or gamma/x-ray) telescopes.
If you quadruple the mirror area of a typical telescope, you quadruple the amount of light power it receives from any given target. That makes it possible to see things twice as far away or four times less energetic.
If you quadruple the arm length of LIGO, you reduce the amplitude of the smallest detectable wave by 4. That makes it possible to see things four times as far away or 16 times less energetic.
Given that we're already detecting events over a billion years ago, a single order of magnitude increase in LIGO arm size should enable the detection of similar ultraviolent events near the beginning of the universe. A two order of magnitude increase in LIGO arm size will increase sensitivity so much that we'll be able to detect events that convert just 0.03 solar masses to energy. A three order of magnitude increase in LIGO arm size (40,000 km, basically a bunch of satellites in geosynchronous orbit) will increase sensitivity to the point that we'll be able to map all the standard type 1a supernovae (the "standard candles") back to the beginning of the universe. The detectors will be seeing a blizzard of events and an array of detectors will be needed to separate out the various events.

In all fairness, using nuclear explosions to test your gravitational wave detector is a bit silly. Most of the interaction occurs well outside the gravitational domain, with very little mass actually converted to energy (mostly what's stored in subatomic bonds, very little, if any, quantum annihilation). Sure, lots of energy is released, but none of it interacts with the detector directly.

Hmm.  Doesn't gravitational radiation consist of transverse waves?  That's what I recall, and that's how it's shown in cartoon representations.  But a nuclear explosion produces a spherically-symmetric longitudinal wave.  GW detectors would only be sensitive to asymmetries in that radiation pattern.  So even if you have the luxury of owning an arsenal of 10^20 Tzar Bombas, you'd need to increase your stockpile substantially to get a detectable bang.  On the other hand, if I understand astronomical distances correctly, the nearest GW source seen so far was at a distance of about a half a light year.  If you set off your bombs at a safe distance - say, about 1 AU or 10 light-minutes away, you'd reduce your stockpile needs by a factor equal to the square of the distance ratio, or (.5LY/10LM)^2, or 10^9.  So you only need to buy about 10^12 bombs, not 10^20.  I bet Jeff Bezos could do this.

I find people's inability to question this result disturbing.  What proof is there that the gravitational forces on earth from the sun would take 18seconds (the speed of travel for the speed of light), why only the results of the Ligo project. And how do we know the LIGO project confirmed gravity waves, well the mirrors moved. Why does this bother me, because their assertion is that matter is affected by gravity, but light waves are not. Given that light can not escape a black hole and that it curves around planets I do not believe this is a correct assumption.  Further more the LIGO only seems to operate when black holes and massive stars collide. Since we can't be sure that normal physicals still apply during a collision of two black holes we can not say what it is that caused the earth to wobble. Gravitational waves must be anywhere there might be mass.  Thus Gravitational waves must be everywhere. I personally believe that LIGO can only detect large "gravitational waves" to the extent that LIGO is good enough to sense them.  JMVHO.

I wish there was more actual real science .. not look for evidence to try and cherry pick to prove a pet theory .. instead real science is one sets up a test designed to falsify the pet theory .. and .. most importantly .. you have a rigorous bunch of scientists in the same field all eager to point out your flaws and mistakes in your conclusions .. not , a one sided bunch of cheerleaders that just nod and go along:


A few examples :
#1> LIGO was hyped as a direct detection of gravitational waves .. even if we blindly accept everything else, this alone should have been jumped on immediately and criticized as a false / incorrect statement / description .. the mechanism is the very definition of a indirect detection .. the actual direct signal was electrical .. that was itself an indirect detection of the light .. the light itself is also not direction detection .. just like they describe how there are soo many other things that can contribute to or cause the variations in the light .. as long as all of those exist .. the behavior one measures in the light itself , is also not a direct measure/detection of anything other than the light itself .. it is indirect / it is inferred / agrees with / etc .. but clearly NOT direct detection of gravitational wave.


#2> They tiny scales .. tiny .. tiny .. they are making claims about .. should have immediately had other peers questioning them about the conflicts with the Uncertainty Principle .. They claim to have very very high levels of certainty on the frequency of the light .. which defines it's momentum .. and they claim to simultaneously have very very high levels of certainty on the exact position of the exact same photon of light at the same time .. This is either .. a big problem .. or .. IF they can actually do both , on such a tiny scale , and to such high levels of certainty .. as they claim .. forget gravitational waves , the bigger event there would be they have evidence that falsifies the uncertainty principle itself even down at tiny subatomic/quantum scales.


#3> At the tiny tiny scales .. the point at which light interacts with the materials matters .. the electrons / atoms are not fixed in time .. they are in flux / waving / vibrating / etc .. and there are many many points in this experiment for this error to easily compound .. They have not shown to be able to know the exact location the photon is emitted at , to the tiny scales they claim to have final results to .. nor have they shown they can know the exact location the photon bounces at , on each and every one of it's bounces , to the tiny scales they claim to have final measured results .. also not the detector itself .. any one of these , and all of these .. all compound to reduce the device's net ability to know it measured a change in the distance between points , and not just the object (photon) bouncing off and interacting at different depths (at this tiny scale) and no change in the space-time itself at all.


#4> There is also another (interesting to me) aspect , not seemingly being discussed much .. the more wide spread consequences , of their conclusions .. it isn't just the distance between emitter , spliter , mirror, mirror, detector .. but the wave length of the photon itself .. shorter is blue shifted photon , longer is red shifted photon .. and (more interestingly to me) changing that photons energy and momentum .. not just the light in LIGO , but all light everywhere (along the gravitational wave's influence) just red/blue shifted by that amount. .. (and even more interesting to me) .. everything else in the entire planet , the entire solar system , the entire galaxy , every gravitationally , chemically, strong nuclear force, weak nuclear force, etc .. bounded objects just moved in relation to each other .. suddenly an enormous amount of stuff (galaxy , super cluster, etc) is a different distance from each other, massively changing net potential energy of the entire bounded system .. one way .. time passes .. then the other way .. their claims of unequal net overall .. means the back and forth does not have a net cancel out +1-1 .. there is a residual net change left in the wake of the passing gravitational wave .. a net change in relative position , energy , and momentum of every object , along the gravitational wave's path , but only along one axis .. ie the path didn't get shorter and then longer , and create no net change in the system .. there was a net change / difference in the wake that they claim to have detected .. and because it had a different net effect on the two arms , it is an unequal unbalanced net change along those two planes.

Well, it makes sense that space is a lot stiffer than steel. Space is continuous, and steel isn't.

Steel is made up of atoms, and atoms are actually quite empty. They have a long distance between nucleuses. So, if you compress a length of steel, that steel is made of trillions if not quintillions of atoms, each one need only compress by less than that thousandth of a proton, to give you inches and feet of compression over the whole length.

Space can't do that, it isn't discrete. It's continuous, it is firmly touching every adjacent piece of space in every direction, because matter has to be able to exist at any place, and if space wasn't continuous, matter would only exist in discrete distances from one spot to the next, and that's not how it works.

Space is the only true solid.
